org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

div1.p: DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE AND LABOR
Immigration Service.
Spokane, Washington, Feb 7, 1912.
Walter P. Harris, Stenographer.
Thomas M. Fisher, Examining Inspector
In the matter of the arrest of SAM PLASTINO
Brother of above called as a witness:
Witness, sworn, testified as follows:

Q BY INSPECTOR FISHER. (To Joe Plastino, brother of Sam Plastino). Your brother, Sam Plastino, has been given a hearing to show his right to be in, or remin in the United States. He states that he wanted an attorney to prepresent him, provided you will furnish the same? A (By Joe Plastion) I am through with him for good and will have nothing to do with hiring an attorney for him.
MICHELE PLASTINO, (father of Sam Plastino), called and sworn, testified as follows:
Joe Plastino, Interpreter in Italian.
Q What is your name? A Michele Plastino.
Q Where were you born? A Italy.
Q Of what country are you now a citizen or subject? A I have taken my first papers as a United States citizen.
Q When did you take those papers? A About twenty years ago.
Michele Plastino (Sam Plastino Case)
Q Have you those paprs now? A Yes, they are home. (Witness agrees to bring papers to Inspector Richardson's office at a lat- er date).
Q Did you ever take any steps towards getting your final papers? A I was going to try but I went back to Italy and then back to the United States again.
Q When did you first come to the United States? A I think in 1881.
Q When did you go back to Italy? A I went back to Italy to sell some property which is still there and a little later returned to the United States at the port of New York about twelve years ago.
Q On what boat did you come to the United States at that time? A I don't know the name but it was a German boat.
Q Who accompanied you at that time? A My son, Sam Plastino.
Q Any one else? A Also my wife.
Q How was Sam Plastino at that time? A About eleven I think.
Q How old is he now? A About 24.
Q Of what country is Sam Plastino a citizen? A He took out first papers in this country; I don't know just when.
Q Has Sam Plastino to your knowledge ever been out of the United States since he entered with out? A No, not to my knowledge.
STATEMENT BY INSPECTOR FISHER:

I examined the naturalization records in U. S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington and find that the record shows that Sam Plastino claimed he was born in Altilia, Italy, September 7, 1886, and came from Naples, Italy, on the s. s. "Abriundra" to the port of New York about the 10th day of June, 1897, and declared his intention to become a citizen of the United States before W. H. Han, Clerk of the U. S. District Court at Spokane, Washington, March 22, 1911.

Sam Plastino was convicted after a hearing in the U. S. District Court at Tacoma, Washington, for violating the White-Slave Traffic Act in that he assisted in the transportation of one Goldie Cardiff from Seattle, Washington, to San Francisco, California, for purposes of prostitution. The evidence adduced at the hearing showed that Sam Plastino had received the earnings of Goldie Cardiff, prostitute, for several years; that he had also received the earnings of two other prostitutes prior and subsequent to his meeting Goldie Cardiff.

After considering the testimony adduced in this case, I find Sam Plastino is an Alien, a citizen of Italy; that he entered the United States through the port of New York during the year 1897; that he has been found receiving, sharing in, and deriving benefit in whole, or in part, from the earnings of a prostitute after his entry into the United States. I therefore respect- fully recommend his deportation to the country whence he came or of which he is a citizen or subject, in conformity with law.
SAM PLASTINO
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a true transcript of the testimony as dictated to me by Inspector Fisher.
(Sg) Walter P. Harris S t e n o g r a p h e r.
